case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Hiralal

facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises the question of the interpretation of Item No. 39 of the Notification No. 58, dated October 24, 1953, hereinafter called the Notification,

facts.text: Notification No. 58 dated October 24, 1953 issued by Government of Madhya Bharat under Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act Samvat 2007 Act No. 30 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Item No. 39 of the Notification No. 58, dated October 24, 1953, hereinafter called the Notification, issued by the Government of Madhya Bharat under the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, Samvat 2007  Act No. 30 of 1950 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Hiralal is the respondent and manager of a joint Hindu family carrying on business as Messrs. Tilokchand Kalyanmal.

anchor.surface_text: Hiralal, the respondent, is the manager of a joint Hindu family carrying on business in the name and style of Messrs. Tilokchand Kalyanmal.

facts.text: The joint family owns a re-rolling mill situated in Indore City called the Central India Iron and Steel Company.

anchor.surface_text: The joint family owns a re-rolling mill situated in Indore City called the Central India Iron and Steel Company.

facts.text: The family purchases scrap iron locally and imports iron plates from outside, converts them into bars, flats and plates in the mill and sells them in the market.

anchor.surface_text: The said family purchases scrap iron locally and imports iron plates from outside and after companyverting them into bars, flats and plates in the Mills sells them in the market.

facts.text: Respondent defaulted in furnishing returns prescribed by s. 7 of the Act for period April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent made a default in furnishing the returns prescribed by s. 7 i  of the Act for the period April 1, 1954, to March 31, 1955.

facts.text: On February 27, 1956, Sales-tax Officer Indore determined taxable turnover at Rs. 2,26,000, sales-tax at Rs. 8,000 and imposed penalty of Rs. 1,000 under s. 14(1)(c) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On February 27, 1956, the Sales-tax Officer, Indore, determined the taxable turnover at Rs. 2,26,000 and the sales-tax payable thereon at Rs. 8,000 and he also imposed a penalty of Rs. 1,000 under s. 14 1  c  of the Act.

facts.text: On the same day, Sales-tax Officer issued demand notices to respondent for payment of sales-tax and penalty.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day he issued demand numberices to the respondent for the payment of the said sales-tax and the penalty.

facts.text: On September 10, 1956, respondent filed petition in High Court of Madhya Bharat under Articles 226 and 227 for writs quashing tax and penalty assessment and restraining State.

anchor.surface_text: On September 10, 1956, the respondent filed a petition in the High Court of Madhya Bharat  afterwards Madhya Pradesh  under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution for the issue of appropriate writs quashing the assessment of tax and penalty and to restrain the State from giving effect to the said orders of the Sales-tax Officer.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court held iron bars, flats and plates sold by respondent exempted from sales-tax under the Notification.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court held that the iron bars, flats and plates sold by the respondent were exempted from sales-tax under the Notification.

facts.text: High Court quashed the orders of the Sales-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: In that view, the orders of the Sales-tax Officer were quashed.

facts.text: The State filed the present appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The state has filed the present appeal, by special leave.

facts.text: Parliament enacted Essential Goods Declaration and Regulation of Tax on Sales or Purchases Act, 1952 (Act No. 52 of 1952), which came into force on August 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Parliament enacted Essential Goods  Declaration and Regulation of Tax on Sales or Purchases  Act, 1952  Act No. 52 of 1952 , which came into force on August 9, 1952.

facts.text: In Schedule I of the Essential Goods Act 1952, iron and steel were declared essential for the life of the community.

anchor.surface_text: In Schedule I of the said Act, iron and steel were declared essential for the life of the companymunity.

facts.text: Government of Madhya Bharat issued Notification No. 58 and Notification No. 59 dated October 24, 1953 under s. 5 of the Essential Goods Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Government of Madhya Bharat, in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 5 of the Act, issued the Notification as also Notification No. 59, dated October 24, 1953.

facts.text: Item No. 39 of Schedule I of Notification 58 exempts iron and steel from tax.

anchor.surface_text: The material part of Schedule I of Notification 58 reads No tax shall be payable on the sale of the following goods - ... 39 Iron and steel.

facts.text: Notification No. 59 Schedule IV No. 9 taxes goods prepared from any metal other than gold and silver at Rs. 3/2/- per cent on sale by importer or producer.

anchor.surface_text: Notification No. 59 described the goods sales of which were taxable at particular rates. Schedule IV thereof reads ... 9 goods prepared from sale by importer or producer. any metal other than gold and silver

facts.text: Counsel for the State contends that iron and steel means iron and steel in original condition and not in shape of bars, flats and plates.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the State companytends that the expression iron and steel means iron and steel in the original companydition and number iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates.

facts.text: Scrap iron purchased by respondent was merely re-rolled into bars, flats and plates.

anchor.surface_text: Scrap iron purchased by the respondent was merely re-rolled into bars, flats and plates.

facts.text: The bars, flats and plates were processed for convenience of sale and did not lose character as iron and steel.

anchor.surface_text: They were processed for companyvenience of sale. The raw-materials were only re-rolled to give them attractive and acceptable forms. They did number in the process lose their character as iron and steel.

facts.text: Dealer sold iron and steel in shape of bars, flats and plates and customer purchased iron and steel in that shape.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer sold iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates and the customer purchased iron and steel in that shape.

facts.text: Bars, flats and plates sold by assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the bars, flats and plates sold by the assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification.

facts.text: Conclusion arrived at by High Court is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion arrived at by the High Court is companyrect.

anchor.surface_text: Subba Rao, J. This appeal by special leave raises the question of the interpretation of Item No. 39 of the Notification No. 58, dated October 24, 1953, hereinafter called the Notification, issued by the Government of Madhya Bharat under the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, Samvat 2007  Act No. 30 of 1950 , hereinafter called the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Iron and steel includes bars, flats and plates produced by re-rolling scrap iron, as they retain character as iron and steel and are not goods prepared from iron and steel.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: rned companynsel for the State companytends that the expression iron and steel means iron and steel in the original companydition and number iron and

anchor.surface_text: Notification No. 59 described the goods sales of which were taxable at particular rates. Schedule IV thereof reads List of articles under section 5 of the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950, on the assessable sale proceeds of which sales tax at the rate of Rs. 3/2/- per cent. shall be payable, showing the nature of articles on which the tax is payable.

concepts.interpretation: Distinguishes and taxes goods prepared from any metal other than gold and silver sold by importer or producer; contrasts with raw iron and steel.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: out the distinction between raw-materials of iron and steel and the goods prepared from iron and steel while the former is exempted from tax, the latt

issues.text: This appeal by special leave raises the question of the interpretation of Item No. 39 of the Notification No. 58, dated October 24, 1953

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises the question of the interpretation of Item No. 39 of the Notification No. 58, dated October 24, 1953, hereinafter called the Notification,

issues.text: The only question in this appeal is whether the said iron bars, flats and plates are iron and steel within the meaning of Item No. 39 of the Notification

anchor.surface_text: The only question in this appeal is whether the said iron bars, flats and plates are iron and steel within the meaning of Item No. 39 of the Notification.

arguments.claim: A comparison of the said two Notifications brings out the distinction between raw-materials of iron and steel and the goods prepared from iron and steel while the former is exempted from tax, the latter is taxed

anchor.surface_text: In our view, this contention is not sound. A comparison of the said two Notifications brings out the distinction between raw-materials of iron and steel and the goods prepared from iron and steel while the former is exempted from tax, the latter is taxed.

arguments.claim: iron and steel used as raw-material for manufacturing other goods are exempted from taxation. So long as iron and steel continue to be raw-materials, they enjoy the exemption

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, iron and steel used as raw-material for manufacturing other goods are exempted from taxation. So long as iron and steel continue to be raw-materials, they enjoy the exemption.

arguments.claim: Scrap iron purchased by the respondent was merely re-rolled into bars, flats and plates. They were processed for convenience of sale. The raw-materials were only re-rolled to give them attractive and acceptable forms. They did not in the process lose their character as iron and steel

The raw-materials were only re-rolled to give them attractive and acceptable forms. They did not in the process lose their character as iron and steel.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that the bars, flats and plates sold by the assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the bars, flats and plates sold by the assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Re-rolling scrap iron into bars, flats, plates for sale convenience does not alter their essential character as iron and steel raw materials, distinguishing from goods prepared from metals under Notification 59.

holdings.text: A comparison of the said two Notifications brings out the distinction between raw-materials of iron and steel and the goods prepared from iron and steel while the former is exempted from tax, the latter is taxed.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, this contention is not sound. A comparison of the said two Notifications brings out the distinction between raw-materials of iron and steel and the goods prepared from iron and steel while the former is exempted from tax, the latter is taxed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of Notification 58 (exempts iron/steel) and 59 (taxes goods prepared from metals) exempts raw iron/steel used in manufacturing other goods.

holdings.text: iron and steel used as raw-material for manufacturing other goods are exempted from taxation. So long as iron and steel continue to be raw-materials, they enjoy the exemption.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, iron and steel used as raw-material for manufacturing other goods are exempted from taxation. So long as iron and steel continue to be raw-materials, they enjoy the exemption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose of exemption under Essential Goods Act protects iron/steel as essential raw materials until transformed into finished goods taxable separately.

holdings.text: Scrap iron purchased by the respondent was merely re-rolled into bars, flats and plates. They were processed for convenience of sale. The raw-materials were only re-rolled to give them attractive and acceptable forms. They did not in the process lose their character as iron and steel.

anchor.surface_text: Scrap iron purchased by the respondent was merely re-rolled into bars, flats and plates. They were processed for convenience of sale. The raw-materials were only re-rolled to give them attractive and acceptable forms. They did not in the process lose their character as iron and steel.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual process of re-rolling scrap does not constitute preparation of new goods from iron/steel but retains raw material identity.

holdings.text: The dealer sold iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates and the customer purchased iron and steel in that shape.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer sold iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates and the customer purchased iron and steel in that shape.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commercial understanding treats re-rolled products as iron/steel.

holdings.text: In our view, this contention is not sound.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the State contends that the expression iron and steel means iron and steel in the original condition and not iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates. In our view, this contention is not sound.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects narrow textual interpretation limiting to 'original condition'; favors broader purposive view.

holdings.text: The conclusion arrived at by the High Court is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion arrived at by the High Court is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court's application of exemption to facts as consistent with SC interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: Scrap iron purchased by the respondent was merely re-rolled into bars, flats and plates. They were processed for convenience of sale. The raw-materials were only re-rolled to give them attractive and acceptable forms. They did not in the process lose their character as iron and steel.
We, therefore, hold that the bars, flats and plates sold by the assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification. The companyclusion arrived at by the High Court is companyrect.
The dealer sold iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates and the customer purchased iron and steel in that shape.
We, therefore, hold that the bars, flats and plates sold by the assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification. The companyclusion arrived at by the High Court is companyrect.
